member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DoesNotReturnAttribute
member.summary: Applied to a method that will never return under any circumstance.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.NotNullWhenAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that when a method returns , the parameter will not be null even if the corresponding type allows it.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.NotNullWhenAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes the attribute with the specified return value condition.
member.param: The return value condition. If the method returns this value, the associated parameter will not be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.NotNullWhenAttribute.ReturnValue
member.summary: Gets the return value condition.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit
member.summary: Reserved to be used by the compiler for tracking metadata. This class should not be used by developers in source code.

member.name: P:GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLDirectiveDefinition.Repeatable
member.summary:
Indicates if the directive may be used repeatedly at a single location.
Repeatable directives are often useful when the same directive should be used with different arguments at a single location, especially in cases where additional information needs to be provided to a type or schema extension via a directive

member.name: T:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind
member.summary: The kind of nodes in the GraphQL document AST (Abstract Syntax Tree).

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Name
member.summary:
Named thing inside GraphQL document: operations, fields, arguments, types, directives, fragments, and variables.
All names must follow the same grammatical form: [_A-Za-z][_0-9A-Za-z]*

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Document
member.summary: A GraphQL Document describes a complete file or request string operated on by a GraphQL service or client. A document contains multiple definitions, either executable or representative of a GraphQL type system.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.OperationDefinition
member.summary: Each operation is represented by an optional operation name and a selection set.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.VariableDefinition
member.summary: A GraphQL operation can be parameterized with variables, maximizing reuse, and avoiding costly string building in clients at runtime.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Variable
member.summary: If not defined as constant (for example, in DefaultValue), a Variable can be supplied for an input value.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.SelectionSet
member.summary: An operation selects the set of information it needs, and will receive exactly that information and nothing more, avoiding over-fetching and under-fetching data.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Field
member.summary: A selection set is primarily composed of fields. A field describes one discrete piece of information available to request within a selection set.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Argument
member.summary: Fields are conceptually functions which return values, and occasionally accept arguments which alter their behavior.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.FragmentSpread
member.summary: Fragments are the primary unit of composition in GraphQL. Fragments allow for the reuse of common repeated selections of fields, reducing duplicated text in the document.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.InlineFragment
member.summary: Fragments can be defined inline within a selection set. This is done to conditionally include fields based on their runtime type.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.FragmentDefinition
member.summary: Fragments are the primary unit of composition in GraphQL. Fragments allow for the reuse of common repeated selections of fields, reducing duplicated text in the document.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.IntValue
member.summary: An integer number is specified without a decimal point or exponent (ex. 1).

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.FloatValue
member.summary: A Float number includes either a decimal point (ex. 1.0) or an exponent (ex. 1e50) or both (ex. 6.0221413e23).

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.StringValue
member.summary: Strings are sequences of characters wrapped in double‐quotes ("). (ex. "Hello World"). White space and other otherwise‐ignored characters are significant within a string value.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.BooleanValue
member.summary: Boolean value. The two keywords true and false represent the two boolean values.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.EnumValue
member.summary: Enum values are represented as unquoted names (ex. MOBILE_WEB). It is recommended that Enum values be "all caps". Enum values are only used in contexts where the precise enumeration type is known. Therefore it’s not necessary to supply an enumeration type name in the literal.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ListValue
member.summary: Lists are ordered sequences of values wrapped in square-brackets [ ]. The values of a List literal may be any value literal or variable (ex. [1, 2, 3]). Commas are optional throughout GraphQL so trailing commas are allowed and repeated commas do not represent missing values.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ObjectValue
member.summary: Input object literal values are unordered lists of keyed input values wrapped in curly-braces { }. The values of an object literal may be any input value literal or variable (ex. { name: "Hello world", score: 1.0 }).

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ObjectField
member.summary: A keyed input value within .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Directive
member.summary: Applied directive. Directives provide a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document. Directives can be used to describe additional information for types, fields, fragments, operations, etc.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.NamedType
member.summary: The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are six kinds of named type definitions in GraphQL, and two wrapping types. In other words all non-wrapping types are referred to as "named types".

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ListType
member.summary: Wrapping type. A GraphQL schema may describe that a field represents a list of another type; the List type is provided for this reason, and wraps another type. A wrapping type has an underlying named type, found by continually unwrapping the type until a named type is found.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.NonNullType
member.summary: Wrapping type. The Non-Null type wraps another type, and denotes that the resulting value will never be null (and that a field error cannot result in a null value). A wrapping type has an underlying named type, found by continually unwrapping the type until a named type is found.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.NullValue
member.summary: Null values are represented as the keyword null.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.SchemaDefinition
member.summary: A GraphQL service’s collective type system capabilities are referred to as that service's "schema".

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.RootOperationTypeDefinition
member.summary: Root operation type for each kind of operation: query, mutation, and subscription; this determines the place in the type system where those operations begin.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ScalarTypeDefinition
member.summary: Scalar types represent primitive leaf values in a GraphQL type system.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ObjectTypeDefinition
member.summary: While Scalar types describe the leaf values of these hierarchical operations, Objects describe the intermediate levels.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.FieldDefinition
member.summary: GraphQL Objects represent a list of named fields, each of which yield a value of a specific type.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.InputValueDefinition
member.summary: Argument name and its expected input type.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.InterfaceTypeDefinition
member.summary: GraphQL interfaces represent a list of named fields and their arguments.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.UnionTypeDefinition
member.summary: GraphQL Unions represent an object that could be one of a list of GraphQL Object types, but provides for no guaranteed fields between those types.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.EnumTypeDefinition
member.summary: GraphQL Enum types, like Scalar types, also represent leaf values in a GraphQL type system. However Enum types describe the set of possible values.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.EnumValueDefinition
member.summary: GraphQL Enum types, like Scalar types, also represent leaf values in a GraphQL type system. However Enum types describe the set of possible values.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.InputObjectTypeDefinition
member.summary: A GraphQL Input Object defines a set of input fields; the input fields are either scalars, enums, or other input objects. This allows arguments to accept arbitrarily complex structs.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ObjectTypeExtension
member.summary: Object type extensions are used to represent a type which has been extended from some original type. For example, this might be used to represent local data, or by a GraphQL service which is itself an extension of another GraphQL service.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.DirectiveDefinition
member.summary: Directive definition. Directives provide a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document. Directives can be used to describe additional information for types, fields, fragments, operations, etc.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Comment
member.summary: GraphQL source documents may contain single‐line comments, starting with the # marker. A comment can contain any Unicode code point except LineTerminator so a comment always consists of all code points starting with the # character up to but not including the line terminator. Comments behave like white space and may appear after any token, or before a line terminator, and have no significance to the semantic meaning of a GraphQL Document.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Description
member.summary: Description of a GraphQL definition.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.TypeCondition
member.summary: Fragments must specify the type they apply to.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Alias
member.summary: By default a field's response key in the response object will use that field's name. However, you can define a different response key by specifying an alias.Fragments must specify the type they apply to.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ScalarTypeExtension
member.summary: Scalar type extensions are used to represent a scalar type which has been extended from some original scalar type. For example, this might be used by a GraphQL tool or service which adds directives to an existing scalar.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.InterfaceTypeExtension
member.summary: Interface type extensions are used to represent an interface which has been extended from some original interface. For example, this might be used to represent common local data on many types, or by a GraphQL service which is itself an extension of another GraphQL service.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.UnionTypeExtension
member.summary: Union type extensions are used to represent a union type which has been extended from some original union type. For example, this might be used to represent additional local data, or by a GraphQL service which is itself an extension of another GraphQL service.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.EnumTypeExtension
member.summary: Enum type extensions are used to represent an enum type which has been extended from some original enum type. For example, this might be used to represent additional local data, or by a GraphQL service which is itself an extension of another GraphQL service.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.InputObjectTypeExtension
member.summary: Input object type extensions are used to represent an input object type which has been extended from some original input object type. For example, this might be used by a GraphQL service which is itself an extension of another GraphQL service.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.SchemaExtension
member.summary: Schema extensions are used to represent a schema which has been extended from an original schema. For example, this might be used by a GraphQL service which adds additional operation types, or additional directives to an existing schema.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ArgumentsDefinition
member.summary: Occasionally object fields/directives can accept arguments to further specify the return value. Object field arguments are defined as a list of all possible argument names and their expected input types.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Arguments
member.summary:
Fields are conceptually functions which return values, and occasionally accept arguments which alter their behavior.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.InputFieldsDefinition
member.summary:
A GraphQL Input Object defines a set of input fields; the input fields are either scalars, enums, or other input objects. This allows arguments to accept arbitrarily complex structs.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.VariablesDefinition
member.summary:
A GraphQL operation can be parameterized with variables, maximizing reuse, and avoiding costly string building in clients at runtime.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.EnumValuesDefinition
member.summary:
GraphQL Enum types, like Scalar types, also represent leaf values in a GraphQL type system. However Enum types describe the set of possible values.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.FieldsDefinition
member.summary:
GraphQL Objects represent a list of named fields, each of which yield a value of a specific type.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.Directives
member.summary:
Applied directive. Directives provide a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document. Directives can be used to describe additional information for types, fields, fragments, operations, etc.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.ImplementsInterfaces
member.summary:
A list of implemented interfaces.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.DirectiveLocations
member.summary:
A list of directive locations.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.UnionMemberTypes
member.summary:
A list of union members.
This node represents a list of .

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.AST.ASTNodeKind.FragmentName
member.summary: Fragments are the primary unit of composition in GraphQL. Fragments allow for the reuse of common repeated selections of fields, reducing duplicated text in the document.

member.name: T:GraphQLParser.AST.DirectiveLocation
member.summary: Directives must only be used in the locations they are declared to belong in. https://graphql.github.io/graphql-spec/June2018/#sec-Type-System.Directives

member.name: T:GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLLocation
member.summary: Provides information regarding the location of a node within a document's original text.

member.name: M:GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLLocation.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance with the specified parameters.

member.name: P:GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLLocation.Start
member.summary:
The index for the start of the node in the source (i.e. it's inclusive).
For example:
{ field { subfield } }
--^ field.Location.Start = 2

member.name: P:GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLLocation.End
member.summary:
The index for the character immediately after the node in the source (i.e. it's exclusive).
For example:
{ field { subfield } }
--------------------^ field.Location.End = 20

member.name: M:GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLLocation.op_Equality(GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLLocation,GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLLocation)
member.summary: Indicates whether one object is equal to another object of the same type.

member.name: T:GraphQLParser.ROM
member.summary:
A wrapper around ReadOnlyMemory{char} allowing you to use simple syntax when working with it.
This struct is designed to unify work with objects of , ans . For example, you can directly pass the string object to all methods accepting .
Marshal.SizeOf(ROM) = Marshal.SizeOf(ReadOnlyMemory{char}) = 16

member.name: T:GraphQLParser.Token
member.summary: Represents a lexical token within GraphQL document.

member.name: M:GraphQLParser.Token.#ctor(GraphQLParser.TokenKind,GraphQLParser.ROM,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance with the specified properties.

member.name: P:GraphQLParser.Token.Kind
member.summary: Kind of token.

member.name: P:GraphQLParser.Token.Start
member.summary:
The index for the start of the token in the source (i.e. it's inclusive).
For example:
{ field { subfield } }
--^ Start = 2

member.name: P:GraphQLParser.Token.End
member.summary:
The index for the character immediately after the token in the source (i.e. it's exclusive).
For example:
{ field { subfield } }
--------------------^ End = 20

member.name: P:GraphQLParser.Token.Value
member.summary: Token value represented as a contiguous region of memory.

member.name: T:GraphQLParser.TokenKind
member.summary: GraphQL token kind.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.TokenKind.EOF
member.summary: End of file.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.TokenKind.NAME
member.summary:
Named thing inside GraphQL document: operations, fields, arguments, types, directives, fragments, and variables.
All names must follow the same grammatical form: [_A-Za-z][_0-9A-Za-z]*

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.TokenKind.INT
member.summary: An integer number is specified without a decimal point or exponent (ex. 1).

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.TokenKind.FLOAT
member.summary: A Float number includes either a decimal point (ex. 1.0) or an exponent (ex. 1e50) or both (ex. 6.0221413e23).

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.TokenKind.STRING
member.summary:
A string value, encoded as either a 'string' or 'block string'
Strings are sequences of characters wrapped in double‐quotes ("). (ex. "Hello World"). White space and other otherwise‐ignored characters are significant within a string value.
Block strings are sequences of characters wrapped in triple‐quotes ("""). White space, line terminators, quote, and backslash characters may all be used unescaped to enable verbatim text. Since block strings represent freeform text often used in indented positions, the string value semantics of a block string excludes uniform indentation and blank initial and trailing lines. Triple-quotes (""") may be escaped as \""" within the block string. No other escape sequences may be used within a block string.
member.remarks: Within a block string, line termination sequences (LF, CR, or CRLF) are always replaced with a line-feed (LF) character.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.TokenKind.COMMENT
member.summary: GraphQL source documents may contain single‐line comments, starting with the # marker. A comment can contain any Unicode code point except LineTerminator so a comment always consists of all code points starting with the # character up to but not including the line terminator. Comments behave like white space and may appear after any token, or before a line terminator, and have no significance to the semantic meaning of a GraphQL Document.

member.name: F:GraphQLParser.TokenKind.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown token. Something went wrong.
